name: Dr. Mike Morgan
bio: Mike trained as a wet lab biologist in rheumatology research and genetics before jumping ship to become a computational biologist during his postdoctoral years in Oxford and Cambridge Universities. He contributed to, and developed his own computational methods and applied these to a range of immunological systems, including the ageing thymus, COVID19 and T cell development.

Mike spends his free time running and hiking the Scottish hills or trying to train his recalcitrant Springador Luna not to go chasing rabbits. Mike is not winning at the moment. He has a strong penchant for Yorkshire Tea (the best there is) and porridge. Mike is well suited to life in Scotland.

name: Haries Ramdhani
bio: Haries joined Morgan Lab in 2023 for his PhD to work on robust and scalable differential cell-to-cell communication method development. Haries is originally from Jakarta, Indonesia, but at this point we can call him a nomad. Prior to joining, Haries earned his BSc from Gebze Technical University in Turkey followed by working as a data scientist for a Czech-based Finance Company.

Haries is interested in bioinformatics software and algorithm development, also the utilisation of omics data to understand the complexity of biological systems through data visualization and machine learning. In his free time he loves watching nature documentaries, quiz shows and animated series. Haries also likes learning new languages (He still keeps his years of Duolingo streaks alive) and hacking random stuff.

name: Calum Bane
bio: Calum joined the Morgan Lab in October 2024 to pursue his PhD, following four years in industry. After graduating from the University of Aberdeen with a BSc in Genetics (Immunology) in 2019, he completed an MSc in Cancer Research at the University of Glasgow before working for Merck from 2020 to 2024. Now, Calum is excited to return to Aberdeen with the Morgan lab and focus on research into CHIP and age-related immune remodelling.
In his spare time, Calum enjoys bagging Munros and staying active, watching football, or simply relaxing with a beer and some music.

name: David Wragg
bio: David, a computational biologist, co-joined the Morgan lab and Kang-Berg lab in Ocobter 2024. He has extensive experience in genomics across a range of species, having worked at the University of Nottingham, INRAe Toulouse, and the Roslin Institute. He is applying single-cell omics to brain organoids to study neurological disorders.

In his spare time, David supports a honey bee genetics community interest company (Beebytes Analystics CIC) he co-founded, exercises two rescue dogs, and entertains his kids. He enjoys watching international rugby, K-dramas, and tabletop gaming.

name: This might be you!
bio: We are always looking for talented scientists to join our team. Please get in touch with Mike if you would like to discuss your research ideas further.
